<%& '/site/header/' %> <% exampleHeader('Cache', 'Service'); %> <% document.executeOnce('/savory/service/cache/') document.executeOnce('/sincerity/json/') document.executeOnce('/sincerity/localization/') document.executeOnce('/sincerity/jvm/') document.executeOnce('/sincerity/xml/') var cache = new Savory.Cache({name: 'result', logLevel: 'info'}) var getResult = function(userId) { Sincerity.JVM.sleep(1000) return {userId: userId, randomValue: Math.random()} } .cache(cache, 10000, 'result.') var start = java.lang.System.currentTimeMillis() var result = getResult(123) var duration = Sincerity.Localization.formatDuration(java.lang.System.currentTimeMillis() - start) %>

In this example we cache the results of a function that purposely delays for a second to return its data. We set our cache duration to 10 seconds. This means that if you keep refreshing this page, only once every 10 seconds will the function be called, and you will see a duration of "1s" for calling the function. Otherwise, the call will simply retrieve the last result from the cache, which should take about 1 millisecond. Take a look at the "results" collection in MongoDB if you are curious as to how the cached data is stored. 

<%= Sincerity.JSON.to(result, true).escapeElements() %>

It took <%= duration %> to fetch this data.
